title: Strictly Come Dancing stars praised by Makaton charity for using sign language
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Strictly Come Dancing’s stars have been celebrated by sign language charities for using Makaton to communicate with hard of hearing or non-verbal viewers.

Chris Ramsey, Saffron Barker, Emma Barton and Michelle Visage have all taken to signing ‘thank you’ to those watching at home every week when they are confirmed safe from the dance-off.

Makaton is a language programme adapted from British Sign Language, which uses signs and symbols as a means of communication for those who have difficulties.

It aims to help some who are non-verbal move at their own pace into developing the skill, often coming with spoken cues to aid them.

Over the past few weeks, more of the celebrities and judges have got involved with the kind gesture, expanding beyond ‘thank you’ to include signs of love and description.

This weekend, Saffron and AJ entered the dancefloor using the signs for Halloween, while head judge Shirley Ballas incorporated the sign for ghost into her entrance as well.

Speaking exclusively to Metro.co.uk, sign language charities have praised the stars for their inclusion, how much it meant for those that use it and what it means to be more inclusive on primetime TV.

Amy Clarke, Digital Assistant at learning disability charity Mencap, told us: ‘It’s fantastic that the judges and contestants on Strictly Come Dancing are using Makaton as it makes the show more accessible for people who have a learning disability, like me.’

‘By using Makaton on the programme, Strictly Come Dancing is helping to raise awareness about learning disability and make people who have a learning disability feel more included in society.

‘I feel that Makaton should be used more often across reality television shows and hope that more programmes will follow suit.’

Strictly stars thank fans by signing their thanks to them once they’re through (Picture: BBC)

‘It’s wonderful to see Strictly stars signing at the beginning of their performance,’ Hannah Anderson, of The Makaton Charity explained. ‘This is supporting the ongoing awareness and highlighting the ease of inclusion by using the Makaton communication system.

‘Keep signing and dancing.’

Amanda Glennon, whose daughter Alice frequently sends videos online to the stars of the show using Makaton, added that it has an amazing impact when stars respond.

‘Alice campaigns for inclusion and it is amazing to see an increase in use of signing on the show,’ she told us.

‘Imagine walking into a room and saying goodbye as you arrive- that’s effectively what the stars of SCD do every week.

‘Something as simple as signing hello not goodbye makes a huge difference to Makaton users.’

Chris had previously explained online why he had decided to make the small gesture, responding to Alice who had sent back a thank you video of her own.

‘This has made my day! I know so many children use Makaton including some of my friends’ children,’ he said. ‘So so happy she saw it and hopefully I get to do it again next week.’

This weekend, Catherine Tyldesley and Johannes Radebe were the fifth couple sent home from the competition after splitting the judges’ in half with the decision on Sunday’s dance-off.

Caroline was the latest star to be eliminated from this year’s show (Picture: BBC)

Facing Mike Bushell and Katya Jones, Cath and Johannes were left in tears when it ultimately came down to head judge Shirley Ballas over who went home.

‘I thought both couples really step it up a notch and this is always the most difficult decision for me,’ she said.

‘But based on a good focus, difficult content, with some really beautiful footwork in there with stronger technical skills for me, cleaner and polished. I’m going to save Mike & Katya.’

The decision infuriated viewers, who had previously disputed the judges’ choice when they decided unanimously to send Dev Griffin and Dianne Buswell home in week three.

Strictly Come Dancing continues Saturday at 7pm with the results show on Sunday at 7.15pm on BBC One.
